fields.physical_description:
WARP: white wool; Z2S; 24 threads per inch (90 per dm).

WEFT:  brown wool; Z spun; unplied; 2 parallel threads per shoot; 2 shoots after each row of knots; 21 knots per inch (81 per dm).

PILE: wool; 8 colours: red, orange, dark green, dark blue, blue, pink, brown, white; asymmetrical knot open to the right and tied around 2 threads; 252 knots per sq. inch (3645 knots per sq. dm).

SIDE FINISH: 3 cords overcast with red wool.

END FINISH: Lower: cut.  Upper: plain weave with red and then white woollen weft, turned and stitched.  Red and green wool plait sewn along fold but bits missing.

DESIGN: Field: red ground with two bands of three stepped and hooked guls, one above the other.  In the centre of each, a pink and blue quartered hexagon within a larger rectangle framed alternately pink and red.  The rectangle is also quartered, with dark green bottom left and top right corners, and white in inner top left and inner lower right.  There is a central band with two lozenge arrangements of eight blue-outlined, small rectangles each containing a white star and framing a geometric, hooked motif outlined in brown.  Similar upper and lower bands are partially evident.

Main border: rectangles with contrasting star-like motif and separated (upper and lower) by narrow blocks of red and (sides) by multi-coloured bands.

Inner and outer borders: pink ground (lower parts have red ground) altnerating with white and red flowerheads outlined in dark green.

Upper border: row of blue, dark green, brown and white horns rise directly from the outer border.

Apron: pile 19 cms. in depth; diagonal row of alternating dark blue and dark green sprigs with white flowers - the dark blue infilled with red or orange and the dark green
[Bag face] WARP: white wool; Z2S; 24 threads per inch (90 per dm).

WEFT: brown wool; Z spun, unplied; 2 parallel threads per shoot; 2 shoots after each row of knots; 21 knots per inch (81 per dm.)

PILE: wool; 8 colours: red, orange, dark green, dark blue, blue, pink, brown, white; asymmetrical knot open to the right and tied around 2 threads; 252 knots per sq. inch (3645 knots per sq. dm).

SIDE FINISH: 3 cords overcast with red wool.

END FINISH: Lower: cut.  Upper: plain weave with red and then white woollen weft, turned and stitched.  Red and green wool plait sewn along fold but bits missing.

DESIGN: field: red ground with two bands of three stepped and hooked guls, one above the other.  In the centre of each, a pink and blue quartered hexagon within a larger rectangle framed alternately pink and red.  The rectangle is also quartered, with dark green bottom left and top right corners, and white in inner top left and inner lower right.  There is a central band with two lozenge arrangements of eight blue-outlined, small rectangles each containing a white star and framing a geometric, hooked motif outlined in brown.  Similar upper and lower bands are partially evident.

Main border: rectangles with contrasting star-like motif and separated (upper and lower)mby narrow blocks of red and (sides) by multi-coloured bands.

Inner and outer borders: pink ground (lower parts have red ground) alternating with white and red flowerheads outlined in dark green.

Upper border: row of blue, dark green, brown and white horns rise dirctly from the outer border.

Apron: pile 19 cms in depth, diagonal rows of altnerating dark blue and dark green sprigs with white flowers - the dark blue infilled with red or orange and the dark green.
[Bag face] Bag face (Salor?)

Warp: white wool; Z2S; 23 threads per inch (91 per dm).

WEFT: brown wool; Z spun, unplied; 2 parallel threads per shoot; 2 shoots after each row of knots; 21 knots per inch (85 per dm).

PILE: wool; 8 colours: dark red, red, dark green, dark blue, blue, pink, brown, white; asymmetrical knot open to the right and tied around 2 threads; 242 knots per sq. inch (3868 per sq. dm).

SIDE FINISH: left: 3 cords overcast with red wool.  Fragments of white warp and weft plain weave stitched with brown and green wool to bag face.  Right: 2 cords overcast, otherwise as above.

END FINISH: Lower: short plain weave with white wool weft turned under.  Upper: cut and missing.  Double plait of red and green wool sewn along length of fold.

NB: Woven with the apron at the top.

DESIGN: field: dark red ground with two bands of stepped and hooked guls, one above the other.  In the centre of each a pink and dark blue quartered hexagon within a rectangle framed alternately in pink and red.  The rectangle is also quartered, with dark green in bottom right and top left corners, and white in inner top right and inner bottom left.  There is a central band of two and two halves lozenge arrangements composed of eitht blue-outlined, small rectangles containing a white star and framing a geometric, hooked motif outlined in browns.  Similar upper and lower bands are partially evident.

Main border: rectangles with contrasting star motifs and separated by multi-coloured blocks - except for top border which has blocks of red.

Inner and outer borders: pink ground; alternating red and white flowerheads outlined in dark green.  Bottom border has row of dark blue, dark green, red and white horns based directly on outer border.

Apron: 19.5 cms. deep; dark red ground.  Diagonal rows of alternating dark blue and dark green sprigs with white flowers; blue sprigs infilled with red, and green sprigs with pink.  14 rows of sprigs, 26 per row; diagonal lines rise to the left.
NB: the knot is open to the right and the diagonal lines of sprigs on the apron rise from bottom right; cf. T.72A-1948

[Bag face] Length: 80 cm maximum, Length: 77.5 cm minimum, Width: 132 cm

fields.credit: P. C. Manuk and Miss G. M. Coles Bequest through The Art Fund
fields.production_note:
Bequest, part of a very large general bequest by P.C. Manuk, Manchester Sq. London W1
one of a "pair of saddlebags (connected to 'juval').  Turcoman (Salor), 19th century.

cf/ A.A. Bogolynbov (ed. Thompson 1973) ill.40, Siawosch Azadi (1975) ill. 10.  See T72-1948 for details.
mentioned "Turkoman Rugs in the V & A", by R. Pinner & M. Franses (intro. by Donald King), analyses by L. Pinner.  Hali 1980, vol. 2, no.4, p.303, 305, 315.
